What is the continental divide and why is it important?
Written by Becky Mathews
Published: March 11, 2023
¬© EQRoy/Shutterstock.com
Share this post on:
Listen to Article
Animals Home
Places
Mountains
What is the continental divide and why is it important?
WATCH: Sharks biting alligators, the most epic lion battles, and MUCH more.
Enter your email in the box below to get the most mind-blowing animal stories and videos delivered directly to your inbox every day.
Thanks for subscribing!
More Great Content:
See a Gator Bite an Electric Eel‚Ä¶
The 15 Deepest Lakes in the United‚Ä¶
Watch an Impossibly Rare Coyote and Bobcat‚Ä¶
The 10 Largest Lizards in the World
The 6 Worst Tornadoes in the United‚Ä¶
The 10 Smartest Animals in the World‚Ä¶
‚Üì Continue Reading To See This Amazing Video
If you‚Äôve heard of the continental divide but wondered what it is exactly, you‚Äôre in the right place! We‚Äôre going to answer the question, ‚ÄúWhat is the continental divide and why is it important?‚Äù We‚Äôll examine how continental divides are made, what they do, and how they affect people and animals.
Continental divides are mountainous geographical features in the landscape that separate rainfall and drain it into different areas.
¬©iStock.com/SeanXu
What Is A Continental Divide?
Continental divides are mountainous geographical features in the landscape that separate rainfall and drain it into different areas.
They are large boundaries that dictate what landmass, rivers, oceans , and in some cases, endorheic basins with no outlets to an ocean, rain or snow melt runs into.
Imagine a mountain range like the Rockies. When it rains overhead, raindrops land on either side of the highest peaks and run downhill in opposite directions. This establishes the flow of rivers and means those rainstorm droplets end up in very different places.  
Simply put, a continental divide is a water drainage divider.
Continental divides are mountainous geographical features in the landscape that separate rainfall.
¬©Nicholas Courtney/Shutterstock.com
America‚Äôs Continental Divide
America has six continental divides dictating where rainfall ends up, but when people say ‚Äúthe continental divide‚Äù they usually mean The Great Continental Divide, sometimes shortened to The Great Divide.
It runs for the most part, along the Rocky Mountains‚Äô highest ridge from Cape Prince of Wales on the Bering Sea coast of Alaska, to the Strait of Magellan, in South America‚Äôs Andes.
It‚Äôs considered the greatest because it‚Äôs the longest and directs water into either the Atlantic or the Pacific ocean.
Rain that falls on the east of the continental divide eventually joins the Atlantic Ocean. It enters the South Platte River and runs through the Mississippi river, New Orleans, and into the Gulf of Mexico.
Rain falling on the western side runs in the opposite direction to the Pacific Ocean via the Colorado River. It travels through Utah, the Hoover Dam, and Las Vegas.
In some cases, water will run into an endorheic basin like Utah‚Äôs Great Salt Lake or Oregon‚Äôs Crater Lake that has no ocean outlets.
The Great Divide runs all the way from Alaska through Mexico and into South America, diverting a massive amount of rainfall and water resources. It is a huge geological feature. The highest point is Colorado‚Äôs Gray‚Äôs Peak with an elevation of 14,270 feet.
Acoma and Zuni tribes built stone bridges and cairns which still stand on the Great Divide Trail.
¬©Grenierb/Shutterstock.com
Central and South America
In Central America , the continental divide runs alongside the Sierra Madre mountain system and the Panama Canal cuts through it. Continuing on to South America , the continental divide runs along the Andes mountain chain. Water falling to the west of the Andes reaches the Pacific ocean and to the east, it finishes in the Atlantic ocean .
How Was It Made?
The Earth‚Äôs crust is formed of seven continental plates that move back and forth.
¬©MattMakesPhotos/Shutterstock.com
The Earth‚Äôs crust is formed of seven continental plates that move back and forth. When they rub against each another they cause earthquakes.
In the distant past, continental plates collided with enormous force, and when a small tectonic plate collided with the North American plate 70 million years ago, it was subducted (pulled beneath). This motion pushed up a towering mountain range we know today as the Great Continental Divide.
It‚Äôs staggering to think the Earth‚Äôs activity so many millions of years ago has such a profound effect on today‚Äôs ecosystems, weather patterns, droughts, and the crop harvest we rely on.
Why is it so Far West?
The continental divide known as The Great Divide is way off center, to the west of the continent. It wasn‚Äôt designed by humans, it‚Äôs an accident of geography that occurred when the world was formed.
When the United States was colonized by Europeans in the 17 th and 18 th centuries, the Great Divide was a marker for the unknown that lay ‚Äòout west‚Äô, and it was a barrier to westward expansion . Lewis and Clark‚Äôs expedition crossed it at the Lehmi Pass in Montana, and settlers crossed through the South Pass in Wyoming.
Thousands of years before settlers arrived, the continental divide was inhabited by indigenous people including the Acoma and Zuni tribes whose stone bridges and cairns still stand on the Great Divide Trail. The highest peaks were sacred to the Blackfeet Nation‚Äôs creation stories. They called the peaks ‚Äúmistakis, the backbone of the world‚Äù.
The United States‚Äô Continental Divides
The continental divide between the European and North American continental plate in Iceland.
¬©Benedikt Juerges/Shutterstock.com
The North American continent contains six mountaintop divides that send water to the Atlantic, the Pacific, and the Arctic oceans, or into landlocked lakes or salt flats.
These are the divides most experts agree on:
Laurentian/ Northern
Arctic
St Lawrence
Eastern
Great Basin
The Great Continental Divide and Laurentian divide converge at Glacier Park‚Äôs Triple Divide Peak in Montana. It‚Äôs a popular tourist spot and so named because from here, water enters three oceans. The Pacific, the Atlantic, and the Arctic Oceans. Experts consider it North America‚Äôs ‚Äòhydrological apex‚Äô.
Why the Continental Divide is Important
Continental divides are important because they determine where, and to whom, fresh water goes. Every living thing on our planet needs water to survive.
Groundwater creates weather patterns, rivers, and streams that irrigate crops and provide water for many habitat regions as it makes its way to the oceans.
It has also created differing cultures and ways of life due to the water resources it provides. Wide open farms that require dams and irrigation systems would look very different if shifted.
If the divide was just a few miles further to the east or west, it would significantly change the U.S. topography, weather, and landmass use as we know it.
What Animals live near the Continental Divide in North America?
Always carry bear spray on the Great Divide Trail and keep your eyes peeled.
¬©Piotr Krzeslak/Shutterstock.com
The Great Divide Trail runs along the continental divide and it‚Äôs packed with interesting, unusual, and sometimes dangerous animals because the habitats are so varied. The trail is one of the country‚Äôs most ecologically diverse. It runs for 3,100 miles through five western states!
Habitats include tundra, coniferous forests, subalpine meadows, craggy snow-covered peaks, grassland , sagebrush, and many miles of rivers and streams all fed by rain falling east or west from the very tip of the continental divide.
It is bear country with both grizzly and black bears in residence. Always carry bear spray on the Great Divide Trail and keep your eyes peeled. Mountain lions are a rare sight, but they do live in the Rockies, as do wolves.
Beavers, yellow-bellied marmots, coyotes, snowshoe hares, pika rodents, boreal toads, and bats have all made it their home, and hikers often spot lots of ungulate species (these are hoofed animals) including deer, elk, bighorn sheep, moose and varieties of cattle.
Bald eagles soar over the mountain tops, white-tailed ptarmigan, mountain chickadee, western tanager, and many species of owls and woodpeckers are loved by birdwatchers there.
 The continental divide is a rich habitat for all species of animals.  
Does Europe Have a Continental Divide?
A marker on Rhine Main Danube canal at the European Continental Divide in Germany.
¬©Steve Heap/Shutterstock.com
Yes, every continent has continental divides except Antarctica, which doesn‚Äôt receive enough rainfall to flow from peaks into drainage basins.
Europe is surrounded by many seas, has many mountain ranges, and therefore many continental divides, but the main one experts agree on (and not all agree!) is the European watershed that separates the northeast bodies of water from the southwest bodies. The northwest bodies are:
Atlantic Ocean
North Sea
Baltic Sea
Arctic Sea
The southern bodies are:
Mediterranean Sea
Adriatic Sea
Aegean Sea
Black Sea
Caspian Sea
The Political Continental Divide
Some commentators refer to the way states tend to regularly vote either democratic or republican as a continental divide. In some cases it refers to the social differences between American and Canadians.
What Is The Continental Divide? Why Is It Important?
Let‚Äôs recap.
The Great Continental Divide is a mountain range created millions of year ago by the Earth‚Äôs continental plate activity. It runs from Alaska to the tip of South America and dictates whether rainfall runs to the Pacific or Atlantic oceans.
It‚Äôs important because it divides water resources. In turn, this creates ecological habitats and weather patterns, so the continental divide dictates where we can successfully grow crops and thrive.
In the past, the continental divide was part of the indigenous nation‚Äôs creation mythology and in the settler period, it was a massive physical barrier to westward expansion.

10 Important Mountains In The Bible
10 Awesome Mountains In Michigan
8 Extinct Volcanoes from Across the World

Wild Hog (Feral Hog) Population by State
Written by Andrew Wood
Updated: February 24, 2023
¬© vlod007 / Flickr / Original
Share this post on:
Listen to Article
Animals Home
All Animals
Mammals
Wild Boar
Wild Hog (Feral Hog) Population by State
WATCH: Sharks biting alligators, the most epic lion battles, and MUCH more.

Thanks for subscribing!

Pause Auto-Scroll
Audio Player Volume
Download audio
More Great Content:
See a Gator Bite an Electric Eel‚Ä¶
The 15 Deepest Lakes in the United‚Ä¶
Watch an Impossibly Rare Coyote and Bobcat‚Ä¶
The 10 Largest Lizards in the World
The 6 Worst Tornadoes in the United‚Ä¶
The 10 Smartest Animals in the World‚Ä¶
‚Üì Continue Reading To See This Amazing Video
Wild hogs are an invasive species that has been multiplying across the United States for centuries and now number in the millions. They do huge economic and ecological damage, carry a lot of different diseases, and can be aggressive toward people and domestic animals. States are using a variety of methods to try to get them under control, including hunting, trapping, poisoning, and sterilization. Humanely decreasing their numbers is vital to preserving the diversity of the natural environment as well as valuable farmland and other private property. Find out in this article where they came from and what is the wild boar population by state.
Wild boars are an invasive species found in most U.S. states. They do tremendous damage to the natural environment and to agricultural land.
¬©iStock.com/chingkai huang
Key Points:
Wild hogs are also known as feral hogs, wild or feral pigs, razorbacks, or wild boars.
They are escaped domestic pigs and their descendants that live and breed in the wild.
Wild hogs in may number 9 million in the U.S. and have been spotted in 40 states.
They do tremendous economic and ecological damage and are considered an invasive species.
Where Did Wild Hogs Come From?
Wild hogs, also called feral hogs, wild or feral pigs, razorbacks, or wild boars, are escaped domestic pigs and their descendants that live and breed in the wild. Domestic pigs originated with the Eurasian wild boar, which was domesticated in ancient times independently by people groups in Europe and Asia.
Pigs were first brought to the New World by Christopher Columbus and released to multiply on islands of the West Indies to provide a food supply for future explorers. This practice continued with other explorers in the 16th-17th centuries in the West Indies and southern parts of what is today the United States. Over the centuries, domestic pigs periodically escaped from farms in the South and joined feral (wild) pig populations. Their numbers today are estimated to be as high as 9 million in the United States.
Wild boar were introduced to Caribbean islands and the mainland of America by early Spanish explorers as a food source for future explorers. Over the years feral hogs have done incredible damage to fragile and unique ecosystems.
¬©Simon Dannhauer/Shutterstock.com
How do Wild Hogs Affect the Environment?
Pigs plow up the ground with their snouts and tusks to find food, unearthing plants and the burrows of ground-dwelling species. They are omnivorous, consuming virtually any type of plant or small animal they can catch. They are particularly devastating to ground-nesting birds , running off the adults, eating eggs, and trampling nesting grounds. They compete with deer and turkeys for some of the same food sources, causing these species to migrate away when food becomes scarce. Studies have shown that the biodiversity of lower vertebrates in forested areas infested with wild hogs is 26% lower than normal.
They also trample, root around in, and wallow in ponds and streams, polluting them for fish or for other animals to drink and introducing disease-bearing bacteria into the water that can go far downstream. In fact, feral pigs can host up to 34 diseases that livestock, wildlife, or human beings can catch from contact with them, eating their meat, or ingesting water they have polluted. Pig farmers are greatly concerned they could bring back swine flu, a respiratory infection that was finally eradicated in the United States in 1978. Fortunately, humans rarely contract this particular disease, but it can be devastating to herds of domestic pigs.
Wild hogs also do tremendous damage to farmland and other private property. They uproot and trample valuable crops in fields, destroy gardens and landscaping, and can break down or root under fences that are not electrified, allowing other animals to escape. They can be quite aggressive and are able to inflict serious injuries with their tusks and teeth. When, on occasion, they wander into the yards of rural homes, they can pose a serious danger to curious pets and children. In Texas , the state with the largest feral hog population, they cost farmers an estimated $50 million a year in damage.
Wild boar have sharp teeth and tusks that can inflict serious injuries on people or pets.
¬©iStock.com/JMrocek
Wild Hog Population by State
Reportedly, as many as 40 of the 50 United States have had sightings of feral hogs. Some states have successfully eradicated their populations, but the best estimates are that at least 28 states currently have established, breeding populations of this damaging invasive species. Estimates of the total number of wild hogs in the country vary but may range as high as 9 million.
The 10 States with Highest Feral Hog Numbers
The 10 states with the largest feral hog populations are Texas (3 million), Oklahoma (1.5 million), Louisiana (750,000), Georgia (600,000), Florida (500,000), New Mexico (500,000), South Carolina (450,000), California (400,000), Hawaii (400,000), and Alabama (250,000).
Wild boar particularly thrive in forested areas of warm southern states, but over the years have made their way as far north as Canada.
¬©iStock.com/Jevtic
Feral Hog Numbers in All 50 States
Here‚Äôs a complete list of the wild boar population by state for all 50 states:
Alabama: 250,000
Alaska: none
Arizona: <1,000
Arkansas: 200,000
California: 400,000
Colorado: none
Connecticut: none
Delaware: none
Florida: 500,000
Georgia: 600,000
Hawaii: 400,000
Idaho: none
Illinois: <20
Indiana: <1,000
Iowa: <1,000
Kansas: 400
Kentucky: 2,000
Louisiana: 750,000
Maine: unknown
Maryland: none
Massachusetts: none
Michigan: 5,000
Minnesota: none
Mississippi: 200,000
Missouri: 100,000
Montana: unknown
Nebraska: unknown
Nevada: unknown
New Hampshire: unknown
New Jersey: <1,000
New Mexico: 500,000
New York: none
North Carolina: 100,000
North Dakota: unknown
Ohio: 2,000
Oklahoma: 1,500,000
Oregon: 5,000
Pennsylvania: 3,000
Rhode Island: none
South Carolina: 450,000
South Dakota: none
Tennessee: unknown
Texas: 3,000,000
Utah: unknown
Vermont: none
Virginia: 3,000
Washington: unknown; sighted in eastern counties
West Virginia: <1,000
Wisconsin: <1,000
Wyoming: none
Wild boar have been sighted in at least 40 states.
¬©iStock.com/JMrocek
How are States Combatting Wild Hogs?
Some of the ways some states are combatting wild hogs include:
Information: Federal, state, and private organizations, as well as academic institutions, study the movements and numbers of wild hogs to try to understand where they are increasing or declining, and why. This can also indicate where they may be close to crossing a state border so that neighboring states can be warned and consider what eradication efforts they might want to make.
Fencing: Agencies and landowners sometimes install specially designed fencing specifically to keep wild hogs out of undesirable areas. Sometimes these are electric fences with 3-4 strands of electric wire set to 16 joules or more, or woven wire fencing with barbed wire on the bottom to prevent wild hogs from rooting under it.
Hunting: Some states have established regular hunting seasons and sometimes incentivize hunters to kill wild hogs. Hunting regulations differ from state to state, but firearms, bowhunting, and trapping are all popular methods. Because wild pigs potentially carry so many diseases, it is imperative that hunters prepare the meat carefully to avoid sickening themselves and their families.
Trapping: This is considered a more efficient method of reducing wild hog populations because it is less time-intensive than hunting. Traps work all the time without continual monitoring.
Poisoning: This is a highly controversial approach because it can inadvertently hurt other species. States that have used this method have set up strict systems of regulations and monitoring.
Sterilization: Surgical sterilization or contraceptives can help reduce wild hog populations . Contraceptives can be dispensed as feed for hogs that will lower the sperm count in feral boars for 30 days. This approach does not kill the hogs, and it can be put in special hog feeders that other species cannot access.
One method of controlling wild hog populations is to set out hog feed laced with contraceptives for them. This reduces male fertility for 30 days, so it must be an ongoing process to have long-term results.
¬©Jaros≈Çaw Pocztarski / CC BY 2.0 ‚Äì License
Some of these methods are cringe-worthy and in some circumstances can be counter-productive. Aggressive hunting, for example, can drive wild hog populations out of remote forests toward populated areas, or into natural biomes that are even more fragile than the ones they are already damaging.
However, wild hogs are clearly a man-made invasive species problem that requires an urgent, thoughtful, and well-coordinated response to protect biodiversity, the rural economy, and the safety of people who live near these wild pests.

About the Author
Andrew Wood
I'm a freelance writer, world traveler, and lifelong animal lover. Currently, I'm an "Emotional Support Human" to 4 dogs, 1 cat, and 2 guinea pigs. My favorite wild animal is the quokka, the most selfie-friendly animal in the world!
FAQs (Frequently Asked Questions) 
How many wild hogs are there in the United States?
No one is sure, but their numbers are estimated at up to 9 million.
What U.S. state has the most wild hogs?
Texas has the most wild hogs, at approximately 3 million.
How did wild hogs get to the United States?
Domestic swine were released in the New World by early explorers to create a food source for explorers and colonists who would come after them. Their numbers multiplied in the wild, with regular additions of escaped pigs from farms.
Why are wild hogs a bad thing?
They are not indigenous to North America in the wild. They damage the biodiversity of habitats by rooting up plants and eating small animals that are food sources for indigenous species. They pollute water supplies by wallowing in streams and ponds. They spread dozens of different diseases, some of which can infect people. They damage farmland and private property as they root for food. They can be aggressive and inflict serious injuries on children and pets.
Thank you for reading! Have some feedback for us? Contact the AZ Animals editorial team .

Bird Quiz: Fast Birds
Most birds do not fly very fast, with cruise speeds in the 20-to-30-mph range. There are birds that achieve a lot higher speeds than this, though. This is especially true for some predatory birds that achieve these speeds when catching their prey.
 
Harry Collins Photography/Shutterstock.com
Harry Collins Photography/Shutterstock.com

Bird Quiz: Flightless Birds
Although we always think of birds as creatures that can fly, there are over 60 species of birds that have lost the ability to fly. They have smaller wing bones than birds that can fly. Some of them evolved to be quite big.
 
vladsilver/Shutterstock.com

Parrots are mostly found in tropical areas and include some of the most intelligent birds in the world. They are well-known for their ability to mimic human speech. Parrots also have some of the most brightly-colored feathers in the bird world.
 
Reto Buehler/Shutterstock.com

Bird Quiz: Bird Migration
Birds migrate to find better ecological conditions, mostly for feeding and breeding. Their survival depends on there being enough resources along the entire route of the migration for them to survive. Some of these birds would fly for thousands of miles yearly to their breeding grounds.
 
ASPhoto2013/Shutterstock.com

Bird Quiz: A Bird‚Äôs Egg
Bird‚Äôs eggs vary in size and color and are specific to the species of bird. The egg contains all the resources for the chick to grow and mature inside the egg. The shell of the egg must be thick enough to withstand the weight of the incubating parent, but still thin enough so that the chick can break through when hatching.

Bird‚Äôs wings are uniquely shaped so that they can fly, being flat underneath and curved on top. This cause a lift under the wing when the bird flaps the wing ‚Äì hence, a flying bird!

Bird Quiz: Prehistoric Birds
Birds began to evolve in the Jurassic period, with the first birds having both reptilian and avian features. The first birds still had teeth and rudimentary claws on their wings. As birds evolved, they acquired more features to make them lighter and more suited for flight.
 
iStock.com/Elenarts108

Man has long been fascinated with bird‚Äôs flight and tries to copy birds to also fly. Birds, however, are uniquely suited for flight. They have evolved with special adaptations that help them fly.

All birds have some form of nest, which ranges from very complicated weaved nests to just basically a hole in the ground. Some weave together twigs and leaves, while others use their saliva to stick together building material.

Bird Quiz: High Flying Birds
Most birds normally fly under 500 feet high, as they expend more energy when flying higher. When birds migrate, however, they fly to heights of up to 20,000 feet. Other birds, like birds of prey, fly higher than this to locate their prey.
 
Cinematographer/Shutterstock.com

Birds are a welcome sight in most gardens, as they help keep the insect population in check. Birds will eat berries, call to each other, and generally create a nice atmosphere. Birds are also fun to watch!

South America is known as the Bird Continent because it boasts the largest number of bird species (3402 to be precise). Of these, the Amazon Basin alone has 806 species. The high rainfall and temperature are conducive to the rainforest environment with its abundance of wildlife.

Bird Quiz: The Bird‚Äôs Bill
A bird‚Äôs bill is an essential part of the bird‚Äôs anatomy. It is very sensitive, having a lot of nerve endings and blood vessels at the point of the bill. A bird uses its bill for a variety of tasks, like grooming and eating, and also to hold onto things as they move.

While we commonly refer to a ‚Äúbird brain‚Äù, birds are more intelligent than most people think. Birds exhibit a wide range of smart behaviors. This include good memories and communication. Some birds even play, which shows a higher level of thinking.

docs.title: Fish Quiz - Can You Identify These 20 Fishes? - AZ Animals
docs.content:
Fish Quiz - Can You Identify These 20 Fishes? - AZ Animals
Fish Quiz ‚Äì Can You Identify These 20 Fishes?
Animals Home
All Animals
Fish
Fish Quiz - Can You Identify These 20 Fishes?
Written by Retha Lombard
Share this on:
How to Play:
Pay close attention to the image and captions provided to help you figure out the answer.
 
Starting in a few seconds..
Start the Quiz
Oldest Living Fish
Imagine discovering a fish thought to be extinct for 66 million years! This is exactly what happened when a fish was discovered off the South African east coast in 1938. This fish is known as a ‚Äúliving fossil‚Äù because it evolved in its present form about 400 million years ago.
 
Catmando/Shutterstock.com
Danny Ye/Shutterstock.com
This fish grow to be just over 6 feet long.
Previous
Next
Which fish is known as a living fossil?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
Blue Whale
Moonfish
Coelacanth
Greenland Shark
Goldfish
Goldfish are most often the fish that novice fishkeepers start with, but this little fish has more to it than it is given credit for. Goldfish are fairly intelligent and can recognize the human that regularly feeds them. Happy goldfish are active little fish that gives hours of entertainment.
 
Aleron Val/Shutterstock.com
Last 4ever/Shutterstock.com
The closest relative to this beautiful fish is a nondescript olive/brown fish.
Previous
Next
Goldfish belong to which family?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
Carp
Cichlids
Tilapias
Catfish
Big Fishes
Fishes vary in length, from the smallest fish ( Paedocypris progenetica ) at under a third of an inch, to the largest, which can reach lengths of 41.5 feet. This largest fish is actually a filter feeder and eat very small organisms!
 
Katja Tsvetkova/Shutterstock.com
Tee Wong/Shutterstock.com
This shark is a gentle creature and harmless to humans.
Previous
Next
What is the largest fish living today?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
Sharptail Mola
Sunfish
Oceanic Manta Ray
Whale Shark
Expensive Fish Products
Beluga caviar is one of the most expensive fish products and a real gourmet dish. This is produced from the roe (eggs) of the female fish. Because this is very high-valued and sought-after, the fishes are seriously over-fished in the wild.
 
Alexander Prokopenko/Shutterstock.com
Thomas Hasenberger/Shutterstock.com
This fish is native to the Caspian and Black Sea basins.
Previous
Next
Which fish produces Beluga caviar?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
Sturgeon
Trout
Whitefish
Angelfish
How Does A Fish Breathe?
Fishes cannot take oxygen out of the air, but rather take dissolved oxygen from the water. A fish has a constant flow of water, passing through its mouth and over the organ that extracts the oxygen.
 
pfluegler-photo/Shutterstock.com
koliw/Shutterstock.com
These organs are situated just behind the head of the fish.
Previous
Next
What organ does a fish use to get oxygen from the water?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
Fins
Lungs
Gills
Swimbladder
Fastest Fish
Fishes are fast swimmers, usually beating a human‚Äôs speed in the water of 5 to 6 miles per hour by far! The fastest fishes, at 70 mph even swim faster than a submarine that can only reach about 50 mph.
 
A Cotton Photo/Shutterstock.com
wildestanimal/Shutterstock.com
This dorsal fin of this fast fish is very big, almost like a sail.
Previous
Next
Which is the fastest swimming fish?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
4-Winged Flying Fish
Great White Shark
Tuna
Sailfish
Marine Tanks
To keep fish is a very rewarding and interesting hobby. Saltwater tanks were always a bit of a mystery with only the select few that managed it. But not anymore ‚Äì with all the new equipment available nowadays, it is easy to keep these very beautiful and interesting fishes.
 
PAUL ATKINSON/Shutterstock.com
Kristina Vackova/Shutterstock.com
This green fish is a popular marine fish for beginners.
Previous
Next
Which popular saltwater tank fish is shown in the photo?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
Firefish
Green Chromis
Yellowtail Damselfish
Coral Beauty
Sportfishing
Recreational fishing is a rich tradition in the USA, with super fishing spots available all around the country. Take for instance the Florida Keys and the Outer Banks in North Carolina. There is also a variety of fish to catch, with some giving the sportsman a real run for his money!
 
Hayk_Shalunts/Shutterstock.com
Colin MacDonald/Shutterstock.com
These blue fish are fast, clever, powerful, and very acrobatic.
Previous
Next
What is the most sought-after saltwater gamefish?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
Blue Marlin
Tuna
Roosterfish
Catfish
Manta Rays
Manta Rays are biologically close to sharks but are not true sharks. They are also very intelligent and have the largest brain-to-size ratio of any cold-blooded fish. They are able to recognize themselves in a mirror, which only dolphins, elephants, and primates can do.
 
Aaronejbull87/Shutterstock.com
chonlasub woravichan/Shutterstock.com
Manta rays feed the same way as the biggest whales.
Previous
Next
What does Manta Rays eat?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
Small fish like sardines
They are filterfeeders
All types of marine creatures
Their favorite food is dolphins
Predatory Fish
Predatory fish are carnivorous fish that actively prey on fish and other marine creatures. Examples of these are shark, billfish, and barracuda. Most of these predators hunt alone, but some hunt in schools. They can be truly terrifying when working together like this.
 
The Jungle Explorer/Shutterstock.com
Jinny Jin/Shutterstock.com
These fish feature in a series of movies, first released in 1978.
Previous
Next
Which South American predatory fish feed as a group on a victim?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
Piranha
Cod
Arapaima
Redtail Catfish
Fish Breeding
Fish can breed in different ways. The most common is for the female to drop the eggs in the water, where it is fertilized by the male. The eggs can also be fertilized inside the female‚Äôs body before she drops them in the water, or she can retain the eggs in her body with the young being born alive.
 
Rich Carey/Shutterstock.com
Marcos del Mazo/Shutterstock.com
These are the slowest swimming fishes in the sea.
Previous
Next
The males of which fish carry the eggs until they hatch?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
Cichlids
Readear Sunfish
Seahorse
Brook Trout
Venomous Fishes
Poisonous fish are poisonous to eat, like the pufferfish that will give serious food poisoning if eaten. Other fishes are venomous and use their poison to actively kill their prey or to defend themselves. They will deliberately deliver the poison by means of a bite, sting, or stab.
 
Matt9122/Shutterstock.com
Vladimir Wrangel/Shutterstock.com
These fish are perfectly camouflaged for their stony habitat.
Previous
Next
Which is the most venomous fish?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
Pufferfish
Electric Eel
Tigerfish
Stonefish
Fish in Cold Water
Fish living in Antarctica have antifreeze glycoproteins that help them survive the freezing water. This, together with the ability to transport oxygen through the body without the need for hemoglobin, cause these fish to thrive at these extreme temperatures.
 
Andrea Izzotti/Shutterstock.com
robert mcgillivray/Shutterstock.com
There are less than 250 species of fish living in Antarctica.
Previous
Next
How many species of fish live around Antarctica in freezing or near-freezing water?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
Approximately 200
175
272
300
Overfishing
When fish are removed from the sea at a rate faster than the fish can reproduce and therefore replenish the population, it is called overfishing. This can lead to serious imbalances and even the eradication of sensitive species like sea turtles and coral.
 
imagIN.gr photography/Shutterstock.com
Damsea/Shutterstock.com
This sea is famous throughout the world for its clear blue waters.
Previous
Next
Which sea or ocean is the most overfished?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
Adriatic Sea
Gulf of Mexico
Mediterranean Sea
Indian Ocean
Famous Fish
Fish have starred prominently in quite a few very enjoyable movies. Take for instance ‚ÄúA Fish called Wanda‚Äù and the ever-popular ‚ÄúFinding Nemo‚Äù, where an overprotective father is looking for his son with the help of a few friends.
 
Alex Stemmers/Shutterstock.com
Kurit afshen/Shutterstock.com
With a name like this, this fish can be in a circus!
Previous
Next
What species of fish was Nemo in the 2003 animation ‚ÄúFinding Nemo‚Äù?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
Yellow Tang
Angelfish
Clownfish
Molly
Beautiful Fish
You get some of the most colorful animals living in the sea. These colorful fish are mostly found in tropical waters. They do not all occur in the sea, however, some of the freshwater cichlid species are also very colorful.
 
Khoroshunova Olga/Shutterstock.com
Halawi/Shutterstock.com
Fish do not like to be caught.
Previous
Next
What is not a reason that fish have colorful patterns on their bodies?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
To serve as camouflage
To mimic another fish
To attract mates
To make them easier to catch
Fish That Can Fly
Flying fish should actually be called ‚Äúgliding fish‚Äù as these fish cannot really fly. They propel themselves out of the water at great speeds and then glide through the air. They can glide for amazing distances.
 
Brent Barnes/Shutterstock.com
feathercollector/Shutterstock.com
These fish have lots of predators!
Previous
Next
Why do flying fish jump out of the water?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
To breathe air
To catch insects
They love to fly
To escape predators
Fish in Symbiotic Relationships
In the ocean, there are quite a few relationships between different animals that can be mutually advantageous. One of these is the relationship between cleaner fishes and bigger fishes.
 
Daniel Lamborn/Shutterstock.com
Stefan Pircher/Shutterstock.com
Fish needs to be cleaned regularly.
Previous
Next
What does a cleaner fish do?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
Eat leftovers
Remove dead skin and parasites from other fishes
Protection from the bigger fish
They like the company
Fish Scales
A fish scale is a small, rigid plate that actually grows out of the skin of the fish. Scales can vary greatly in size, from rigid plates in fishes like boxfishes, to being almost absent in eels and anglerfishes.
 
koifish/Shutterstock.com
Jake Schiele/Shutterstock.com
Fish scales have a variety of uses.
Previous
Next
Why do fish have scales?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
Protect the fish‚Äôs skin from predators
Reduce water resistance
Protect the inner organs of the fish
All of the above
Schooling
A school of fish is a group of the same fish species swimming and turning together. Fish sometimes do this at certain times of the year, or under certain conditions, like the yearly sardine run along the east coast of South Africa.
 
NaturePicsFilms/Shutterstock.com
CyberEak/Shutterstock.com
There are many advantages to living in a school.
Previous
Next
Why do fish swim in schools?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
Defence against predators
To save energy
To find food easier
All of the above

docs.title: üê¥ Horse Quiz - Test Your Equestrian Knowledge - AZ Animals
docs.content:
üê¥ Horse Quiz - Test Your Equestrian Knowledge - AZ Animals
üê¥ Horse Quiz ‚Äì Test Your Equestrian Knowledge
Animals Home
All Animals
Mammals
Horse
üê¥ Horse Quiz - Test Your Equestrian Knowledge
Written by Retha Lombard
Share this on:
How to Play:
Pay close attention to the image and captions provided to help you figure out the answer.
 
Starting in a few seconds..
Start the Quiz
Horse Races
Horse racing first originated among the ancient tribesmen of Central Asia in about 4 500 BC. The first documented horse race was held in France in 1651 when two noblemen entered into a wager. In the US it is thought that the first horse races started with the occupation of New York City in the 1600s.
 
Cheryl Ann Quigley/Shutterstock.com
Cheryl Ann Quigley/Shutterstock.com
This race takes place in Louisville.
Previous
Next
Which famous race horse takes place on the first Saturday of May each year in Louisville?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
Preakness Stakes
Kentucky Derby
The Everest
Durban July
Race Speed
Horse races are run over various distances, with an average distance of five or six furlongs (220 yards). Horses will run the six-furlong race in an average time of 1 minute and 12 seconds. Juvenile horses normally start with the five-furlong race.
 
Anaite/Shutterstock.com
gabriel12/Shutterstock.com
This thoroughbred horse even has ‚Äúwinner‚Äù in its name!
Previous
Next
Which race horse recorded the fastest speed (43.97 mph) over two furlongs?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
Winning Brew
War Admiral
Secretariat
Seabiscuit
Medieval Sport
Medieval knights had tournaments where the knights competed in various sports. This was seen as part of their training as knights. Knights won a lot of prestige by being the best at a tournament.
 
Gary Perkin/Shutterstock.com
strannik72/Shutterstock.com
Nowadays this word is used to show two teams competing against each other.
Previous
Next
Which medieval sport involved two riders striking at each other with lances?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
Curling
Skittles
Quintain
Jousting
Prehistoric Horses
Horses share a common ancestry with tapirs and rhinoceros. They all have hooved feet an odd number of toes and mobile upper lips. The earliest ancestor of the modern horse was a small animal, about the size of a fox, that lived 53 million years ago.
 
Daniel Eskridge/Shutterstock.com
Jirik V/Shutterstock.com
The name of this early horse means ‚Äúdawn horse‚Äù.
Previous
Next
Which prehistoric animal did the horse evolve from?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
Entelodon
Oculudentavis
Eohippus
Indricotherium
The Biggest Horses
Horses come in a lot of different sizes, with an average horse being around 5 feet tall and weighing 800-1200 pounds. There are, however, exceptions to this, with some horses growing to a massive 17 hands and a weight of up to 2,400 pounds.
 
Alla-L/Shutterstock.com
Simev/Shutterstock.com
One can almost think that this horse is from Lord of the Rings!
Previous
Next
Which is the biggest horse breed?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
Shire
Belgian Draft Horse
Clydesdale
American Cream Draft
Horse‚Äôs Feet
Horse feet continually grow, much like our nails. Most horses cannot wear this down on their own, and this excess growth has to be trimmed off. Horses are also fitted with steel shoes that protect their feet.
 
Eugenie Photography/Shutterstock.com
MarienAvery/Shutterstock.com
This is one of he oldest professions relating to horses.
Previous
Next
What is the name of the person who trims the horse‚Äôs feet?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
Equine-assisted therapist
Horse trainer
Equine Nutritionist
Farrier
How to Measure Horses
Horses are measured from the ground up. The unit that is used to measure a horse, is ‚Äúhands‚Äù, where one hand is 4 inches. This measurement originated in ancient Egypt. A horse that is 17 hands high, is considered a big horse, while a pony is any horse under 14.2 hands.
 
arthorse/Shutterstock.com
Wynn Dhyana/Shutterstock.com
This is the highest part of the horse‚Äôs back.
Previous
Next
To which body part do you measure a horse?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
Chest
Its withers
Top of the head
Its rump
Horses in the USA
Horses are very popular in the USA, in fact, it is the country with the most horses in the world. Americans have a long history with horses since it was introduced into North America by Hern√°n Cort√©s in 1519. This range from the native Americans who immediately took to horse riding, as well as the cowboys who tamed the West on their trusted horses.
 
Jaco Wiid/Shutterstock.com
Jaco Wiid/Shutterstock.com
This American horse is the most popular in the US.
Previous
Next
What horse breed is the most popular in the United States?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
Arabian Horse
Mustang
American Quarter Horse
Thoroughbred
Wild Horses
Although there are nearly 80,000 ‚Äúwild‚Äù horses living on public land across 10 western US states, these horses are not considered truly wild horses. They are rather feral horses, as they are descended from domesticated horses. The only truly wild horse lives on the steppe in Central Asia.
 
Yantar/Shutterstock.com
PhotocechCZ/Shutterstock.com
These horses are native to Central Asia.
Previous
Next
What is the name of the only surviving species of wild horses?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
Akhal-Teke
Appaloosa
Mustang
Przewalski‚Äôs horse
Horse Shows
Horse shows are competitions between riders and their horses in various disciplines. The horse is judged according to its movements, style of jumping, and general manners. The best horses can earn lots of prize money and will also be in demand for breeding.
 
Rolf Dannenberg/Shutterstock.com
pirita/Shutterstock.com
This is basically the groundwork for many other disciplines.
Previous
Next
What is an equestrian sport where the horse is ridden in such a way that it develops obedience, flexibility, and balance?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
3-day Eventing
Dressage
Skijoring
Show Jumping
Riding a Horse
Riding a horse can be quite an adrenaline rush. It also gives the rider as well as the horse a very good workout. It can take years to become a really good rider, depending on how often you ride. It is best to get a mentor to teach you the basics of riding.
 
FXQuadro/Shutterstock.com
Cool_photo/Shutterstock.com
There are a number of important factors to remember when riding a horse.
Previous
Next
What are the physical cues used to direct a horse?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
Reins
Your legs
Your seat
All of the above
Ponies
Ponies are small members of the horse family, standing less than 4 feet tall. They can easily be mistaken for just small horses, but ponies have their own characteristics and temperament. Ponies are also usually stockier than regular horses, with shorter legs and heavier bodies.
 
nigel baker photography/Shutterstock.com
Elena Dijour/Shutterstock.com
Ponies can be used for a variety of tasks.
Previous
Next
What is a well-trained pony good for?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
Teaching children to ride
Pulling a cart or sled
Trial riding
All of the above
Famous Horses
One of the famous horses in history was George Washington‚Äôs horse that he rode most during the Civil War. It was important to have a horse that was not too skittish during a battle with cannon balls falling around you. George Washington was a very good horseman, having perfected his skill as a planter and a military man.
 
This horse has the same name as that of a famous South African president.
Previous
Next
What was the name of George Washington‚Äôs favorite horse?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
Lysithea
Nelson
Fancy
Lady
Horses as Characters in Books
Anna Sewel wrote a beautiful book, which is actually an autobiography of a horse. The horse itself is the narrator of the story. It tells the story of how a well-bred horse is progressively sold to crueler masters. The horse makes all sorts of observations leading the reader to understand human nature better.
 
Tamara Didenko/Shutterstock.com
Makarova Viktoria/Shutterstock.com
The story of this black horse was also made into a film.
Previous
Next
A horse is the title character in which 19th century children‚Äôs classic novel by Anna Sewell?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
Paaliaq
Shadow of the Moon
Black Beauty
Twilight Zone
Mythical Horses
Horses were revered in ancient Greek and were seen as symbols of wealth, status, and power. They also feature prominently in Greek mythology, with the goddess Athena who showed mankind how to tame a horse.
 
Ironika/Shutterstock.com
Toshauna/Shutterstock.com
The name of this horse was taken by a Turkish low-cost airline.
Previous
Next
Which winged horse was fathered by Poseidon in Greek mythology?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
Svadilfari
Pegasus
Hugin
Aethon
Triple Crown
The Triple Crown is the name given to three races for three-year-olds on the American calendar, the Kentucky Derby, the Preakness, and the Belmont Stakes. Only 13 horses have ever won the Triple Crown. In 1973 an outstanding horse won this crown in a record-breaking time for all three races.
 
Music4mix/Shutterstock.com
Anaite/Shutterstock.com
A film with the same name was made of the horse‚Äôs story, starring Diane Lane and John Malkovich.
Previous
Next
In the year 1973, which horse won the Triple Crown?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
Secretariat
Seabiscuit
Count Fleet
Justify
High Jumping Horses
Jumping a horse is part of quite a few other equestrian events, for instance, eventing and dressage. Horses are trained for quite a few years before they can really jump very high, as this is quite a technical sport. The highest jump ever was recorded in Chile in 1949, with a jump of 8ft 1in. This record still stands today.
 
horsemen/Shutterstock.com
pirita/Shutterstock.com
This horse first had an English name and was renamed.
Previous
Next
Which horse hold the world record for the highest jump?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
Yancy
Babeica
Cisco
Huaso ex-Faithful
Expensive Horses
Thoroughbreds are the most expensive horses. These horses are mostly used in racing. The most expensive ever was Fusaichi Pegasus. He won $2million racing before his fifth birthday. He was then sold with the expectation that his offspring would produce winners.
 
By Searobin ‚Äì Searobin's file, CC BY-SA 3.0, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=1567569
Callipso88/Shutterstock.com
Fusaichi Pegasus was sold for more than $60 million.
Previous
Next
For what amount was Fusaichi Pegasus sold?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
$70 million
$15 million
$32 million
$2,5 million
Horse Color
Horses can vary in color from pure white to black, with all shades in between. Some of these colors are given specific names. Brown horses, for instance, can be either a bay or chestnut, while piebald horses have irregular patches of white and black.
 
Kwadrat/Shutterstock.com
Kwadrat/Shutterstock.com
The horse‚Äôs name means ‚Äúdove-like‚Äù.
Previous
Next
What is a horse called with a golden body and a white or silver tail?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
Sorrel
Pinto
Skewbald
Palomino
Smallest Horses
Ponies and mini horses are adorable members of the horse family. They are small and have great personalities, making them the ideal pets, especially for families with young children.
 
Fiery Phoenix/Shutterstock.com
horsemen/Shutterstock.com
This beautiful little horse likely originated in Argentina.
Previous
Next
What is the smallest breed of horse?
Correct

Need Help? Clue is here
Falabella
Shetland pony
Noma Pony
Icelandic Horse

docs.title: ü¶à Shark Trivia - Are They Really The Monsters Of The Deep, Or Are There More To Them? - AZ Animals
docs.content:
ü¶à Shark Trivia - Are They Really The Monsters Of The Deep, Or Are There More To Them? - AZ Animals
Shark Trivia ‚Äì Are They Really The Monsters Of The Deep, Or Are There More To Them?
Animals Home
All Animals
Fish
Sharks
Shark Trivia - Are They Really The Monsters Of The Deep, Or Are There More To Them?
Written by Retha Lombard
Share this on:
How to Play:
Pay close attention to the image and captions provided to help you figure out the answer.
 
Starting in a few seconds..
Start the Quiz
Key Points
Sharks can swim about 30 times faster than a human.
The largest shark species include the Great White, Greenland, Tiger, and Whale Sharks.
Wild sharks are not generally interested in attacking humans, that said, there are about 72 recorded incidents each year.
Biggest Sharks
Sharks vary in size from tiny sharks to the biggest, which can be as large as 60 feet. The average female shark is 15-16 feet long, while males can reach 11-13 feet. Although this is bigger than a human, not all sharks will attack humans!
 
Onusa Putapitak/Shutterstock.com
Lindsey Lu/Shutterstock.com
These sharks are so big, they remind us of the biggest mammals in the ocean.
Previous
Next
What is the largest shark species?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
Great White
Whale Shark
Greenland Shark
Tiger Shark
Shark Teeth
Sharks do not only have one row of teeth like most animals but have several, with the average being five. Sharks can have as many as 3,000 teeth at once! The teeth are designed to be disposable and are being replaced continuously as they are broken off or damaged. The teeth in the back rows just move forward.
 
Martin Prochazkacz/Shutterstock.com
Alessandro De Maddalena/Shutterstock.com
Great Whites do not have more than 60,000 teeth in their lifetimes.
Previous
Next
How many teeth does a Great White Shark use in its lifetime?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
Up to 50,000
About 10,000
Up to 80,000
About 15,000
Fast Sharks
Sharks are really built for speed and can achieve high speeds underwater. The fastest shark can swim about 30 times faster than the average human. Sharks swim so fast because their tails swing from side to side. This creates twice as many jets of water and makes swimming much more efficient.
 
Xavier ELIAS Photography/Shutterstock.com
wildestanimal/Shutterstock.com
These short-finned sharks are found in tropical and temperate offshore waters.
Previous
Next
Which shark is the fastest swimmer?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
Copper shark
Great Hammerhead shark
Blacktip shark
Shortfin Mako shark
A Shark‚Äôs Bite Force
Sharks have a massive bite force, with big sharks exerting a bite force of nearly 1.8 tonnes. This gives them one of the biggest bite forces of any living animal, 3 times more than a lion and more than 20 times more than a human.
 
Carlos Grillo/Shutterstock.com
Carlos Grillo/Shutterstock.com
This shark is not as big as the greatest sharks.
Previous
Next
Which shark has the strongest bite force per body length?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
Grey Reef shark
Frilled shark
Bull shark
Great White shark
Tiger Sharks Eat Anything
A tiger shark is a voracious predator that will literally eat anything. They will eat anything from other sharks, fish, and crustaceans, to rays, and seabirds. They are indiscriminate eaters who will also eat non-food items when they find it in the ocean.
 
Tomas Kotouc/Shutterstock.com
le bouil baptiste/Shutterstock.com
A tiger shark will eat almost anything!
Previous
Next
What are the weirdest things found in the stomach of a tiger shark?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
A porcupine
A full suit of armor
A polar bear
All of the above
Earliest Sharks
The biggest shark that ever lived, weighed as much as 30 Great White sharks put together. It was a fearsome hunter, preying on the early whales and other sea creatures. It is thought that the reduction in the availability of prey pushed it to extinction three million years ago.
 
racksuz/Shutterstock.com
Antonio Viesa/Shutterstock.com
This was truly a ‚Äúmega‚Äù shark!
Previous
Next
What was the biggest shark (and fish) that ever lived, called?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
Megalodon
Livyatan
Coelacanth
Astraspis
Shark Attacks
Worldwide there is an average of 72 unprovoked shark attacks yearly, of which an average of 4.3 was fatal. Sharks normally won‚Äôt attack humans and would rather eat fish and other sea creatures, but sometimes a human gets mistaken for a seal or sea lion.
 
Willyam Bradberry/Shutterstock.com
Willyam Bradberry/Shutterstock.com
These huge white sharks are very aggressive.
Previous
Next
Which shark is responsible for most shark attacks?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
Caribbean Reef shark
Blue shark
Great White shark
Blacktip shark
Smallest Shark
When talking about sharks, people tend to concentrate on the massive ones, like Megalodon and the Great White shark. But there are quite a few species of shark that will fit in the palm of your hand and are quite harmless to humans.
 
By Javontaevious ‚Äì Took a photographPreviously published: Javontae [email protected] Facebook, CC BY-SA 3.0, https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?curid=37516033
This small shark glow in the dark.
Previous
Next
Which is the smallest shark species?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
Smalleye Pigmy Shark
School Shark
Sand Tiger Shark
Dwarf Lanternshark
A Shark‚Äôs Sense of Smell
Sharks have about the same sense of smell as other fish and can smell blood that is diluted between one part per 25 million and one part per 10 billion, making it about one drop of blood in a small swimming pool. Sharks are drawn to the smell of blood and will attack an injured animal or human.
 
J nel/Shutterstock.com
Sergey Uryadnikov/Shutterstock.com
A shark will smell blood less than half a mile away.
Previous
Next
How far away can sharks smell blood under water?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
A quarter of a mile
One mile
Half a mile
300 yards
Shark Embryos
Shark embryos, stuck inside the egg case, are very vulnerable to a variety of predators. As the egg case starts to open, predators can sense the baby inside through changing electric fields. The embryo can, however, also sense the danger approaching by the same means.
 
Daniel Majak/Shutterstock.com
JoLin/Shutterstock.com
Baby sharks almost ‚Äúplay dead‚Äù when they sense danger
Previous
Next
What does a shark embryo do to hide from predators?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
They are completely helpless, cannot do anything
They wiggle into sea grass
They ‚Äúfreeze‚Äù, even stop breathing
They secrete a foul substance
Buoyant Sharks
Fishes and underwater creatures need to achieve neutral buoyancy. They can do this in different ways. Most fishes have a swimbladder that is filled with different volumes of gas. Other fishes store fats and lipds that is less dense than water and others balance blubber and bone.
 
BlueRingMedia/Shutterstock.com
wildestanimal/Shutterstock.com
This organ is huge and contain lots of oil.
Previous
Next
Which organ in the shark‚Äôs body help them stay afloat?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
Liver
Swim bladder
Lungs
Stomach
Sharks‚Äô Predators
Sharks have long been considered the top predator in the ocean, but there are animals that make a feast of shark meat. These include large fishes like the grouper as well as other animals.
 
slowmotiongli/Shutterstock.com
Tory Kallman/Shutterstock.com
This killer of sharks is actually a dolphin!
Previous
Next
Which animal will kill sharks?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
Jellyfish
Killer whale
Blue whale
Bluefin Tuna
Prehistoric-looking Sharks
The Hexanchiformes are the most primitive sharks alive today. They are strange, prehistoric-looking sharks that spend most of their time in the deep waters of the oceans far below the surface.
 
iStock.com/3dsam79
iStock.com/3dsam79
These sharks have collar-looking gills, almost like frills.
Previous
Next
Which shark looks a lot like a sea serpent and hovers in the water?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
Dusky Shark
Porbeagle
Cookie Cutter Shark
Frilled Shark
Oldest Living Species of Shark
Sharks first appeared about 380 million years ago. The golden age of sharks was the Carboniferous Period when sharks dominated and evolved in lots of different forms. Some of the sharks from that period are still around today.
 
Peter Halasz / CC BY-SA 3.0
Dianne Bray / Museum Victoria / CC BY 3.0 AU, Wikimedia Commons
The name of this shark refers to a small, grotesque, monstrous creature from folklore.
Previous
Next
Which species of shark has been living in the oceans since 125 million years ago?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
Pyjama Shark
Goblin Shark
Common Thresher
Megamouth Shark
Sharks in Freshwater
Sharks have evolved in saltwater and are adapted for a life in saltwater. They must retain salt inside their bodies, otherwise, their cells would rupture and they would die. There are, however, a few species of sharks that can tolerate fresh water for a certain time period.
 
This is one of the most aggressive sharks.
Previous
Next
Which sharks can survive for long periods in freshwater?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
Spiny Dogfish
Great White Shark
Bull Shark
Lemon Shark
Shark Skeleton
Because sharks have no swim bladder, their skeleton needs to be lighter to aid with buoyancy in the water. Sharks have therefore evolved to have a lighter skeleton than land animals and even other fishes.
 
Jayaprasanna T.L/Shutterstock.com
Fata Morgana by Andrew Marriott/Shutterstock.com
The whale shark has got to have very light skeleton to stay afloat.
Previous
Next
What is a shark skeleton made of?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
Bone
Cartilage
Keratin
They do not have skeletons
Hammerhead Sharks
Hammerhead sharks can be recognized by their unusually shaped head. The Hammerhead has electrical sensors in the head that allows it to scan for food quickly. The Hammerhead has 360-degree vision because its eyes are placed on the sides of the hammerhead.
 
Brent Barnes/Shutterstock.com
CHEN MIN CHUN/Shutterstock.com
A hammerhead with its favorite prey, a stingray.
Previous
Next
What does a Hammerhead shark use its head for?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
To hammer other fishes
It has no special function
To pin and trap its favorite prey, stingrays
It supports the eyes
Longest Living Sharks
Sharks have various lifespans, depending on the species. Some sharks do not live very long, like the Blue shark which only lives 15 to 16 years in the wild. Other shark species live incredibly long lives, and only mature at around 150 years of age!
 
Dotted Yeti/Shutterstock.com
Dotted Yeti/Shutterstock.com
These sharks live in very cold waters.
Previous
Next
Which shark lives the longest?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
Greenland Shark
Tiger Shark
Sandbar Shark
Galapagos Shark
Famous Sharks
Sharks have featured in a lot of movies over time. Who will forget the greatest shaw movie of all time, Jaws? But not all sharks are monsters like the shark in Jaws ‚Äì there are also very likable characters, like the friendly shark in Finding Nemo!
 
Stefan Pircher/Shutterstock.com
Fiona Ayerst/Shutterstock.com
The shark was named after the villainous shark in the movie ‚ÄúJaws‚Äù.
Previous
Next
What is the name of the Great White that is the leader of the Fish-Friendly Sharks Support Group in Finding Nemo?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
Sharky
Mr Ray
Bruce
Marlin
Sharks in Religion
In some countries, sharks are considered sacred. They are revered as departed relatives that inhabited the body of a shark and will act as family guardians. They are also considered to give guidance to travelers at sea.
 
Shane Myers Photography/Shutterstock.com
Willyam Bradberry/Shutterstock.com
In this culture it is believed that sharks give guidance.
Previous
Next
Where are sharks worshipped, with 9 shark gods in the culture?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
Antarctica
Iceland
Galapagos
Hawaii

docs.title: Wolf Quiz - What is Special About These Family Animals? - AZ Animals
docs.content:
Wolf Quiz - What is Special About These Family Animals? - AZ Animals
Wolf Quiz ‚Äì What is Special About These Family Animals?
Animals Home
All Animals
Mammals
Wolves
Wolf Quiz - What is Special About These Family Animals?
Written by Retha Lombard
Share this on:
How to Play:
Pay close attention to the image and captions provided to help you figure out the answer.
 
Starting in a few seconds..
Start the Quiz
Wolf Packs
Wolves have a highly organized social structure. They live and hunt together as packs, which enables them to hunt and defend their territory effectively. Some packs can be as many as 30 wolves, but then some wolves will break away to form their own breeding packs.
 
AB Photographie/Shutterstock.com
Alan Jeffery/Shutterstock.com
Wolf packs do not have a clear leader.
Previous
Next
What popular misconception is there about wolf packs?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
Most packs have 4 to 9 members
Every pack has an alpha wolf
One pack will fight another when they encroach on its territory
Wolves sleep together as a pack
Wolves Howling
Wolves have 4 main sounds that they use to communicate in different ways ‚Äì howling, barking, whimpering, and growling. A wolf uses howls to call to each other over great distances; a wolf‚Äôs howl can be heard for up to 10 miles away on open terrain.
 
ortlemma/Shutterstock.com
Allison Coffin/Shutterstock.com
There can be a variety of reasons why a wolf howls.
Previous
Next
Why do wolves howl?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
To tell other members of the pack where they are
Warn off rival packs from their territory
Show their affection for members of their own pack
All of the above
Interacting In The Pack
Wolves living in a pack have strong emotional bonds with each other. The pack also makes it easier to raise pups, hunt, and defend their territory. They have to communicate with each other in the pack and do this with growls, howls, and body language.
 
Pat-s pictures/Shutterstock.com
Pat-s pictures/Shutterstock.com
Dogs can also be seen doing this.
Previous
Next
How do wolves greet each other?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
Licking each other‚Äôs faces
Sniffing at each other
Staring at the other wolf
Bumping against the other wolf
Wolf Cubs
A wolf has a gestation period of 63 days, with the cubs being born pretty much helpless. They can waddle around by about 2 weeks and leave the den for the first time by three weeks. All the members of the pack help to take care of the cubs.
 
Art Babych/Shutterstock.com
Bildagentur Zoonar GmbH/Shutterstock.com
Wolf cubs are born helpless, but with their important senses.
Previous
Next
Which of the following is not true about newborn wolf cubs?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
They are deaf
They are blind
They often have blue eyes
They do not have any sense of smell
How Fast Are Wolves
Wolves are not usually known for their speed, but rather their endurance. They can run great distances at a speed of about 5 miles per hour. They are, however, faster than a human so it will not help to try and outrun a wolf!
 
Sergijimenez/Shutterstock.com
Warren Metcalf/Shutterstock.com
A wolf can run 19mph faster than the average human.
Previous
Next
How fast can the fastest wolf, the Arctic wolf, run?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
21mph
38mph
26mph
46mph
Wolves in Mythology
Wolves feature in the mythology of various nations. There is, for instance, Fenrir, the son of the god Loki and a giantess, Angerboda in Norse mythology. Odin also had two wolves as loyal companions. We all also know stories like Little Red Ridinghood and the Three Little Pigs, that feature a wolf prominently.
 
De Jongh Photography/Shutterstock.com
Cris Foto/Shutterstock.com
These twin babies found Rome.
Previous
Next
Which 2 children were raised by wolves in Roman mythology?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
Romulus and Remus
Laurel and Hardy
Cheech and Chong
Fred and Barney
Wolves in Conservation
Wolves have a key role in ecosystems and are what is called a keystone species. They keep the populations of deer and elk in check, which in turn have a positive influence on plant species. The carcasses of their prey also help scavengers.
 
MedstockPhotos/Shutterstock.com
Lorcel/Shutterstock.com
Very big park partially in Wyoming.
Previous
Next
Which park reintroduced wolves after there were no more wolves in the park?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
Glacier National Park
Grand Canyon
Yellowstone National Park
Rocky Mountain National Park
Wolf Cub Food
When wolf cubs are born, they weigh only about one pound but grow very quickly. At first, they only drink mother‚Äôs milk, feeding about 4 ‚Äì 5 times per day. They will open their eyes at about 12 to 15 days and start to move on to other food as well.
 
outdoorsman/Shutterstock.com
COULANGES/Shutterstock.com
Wolf cubs licks an adult‚Äôs mouth to get it to regurgitate meat.
Previous
Next
What does wolf cubs eat from about two weeks old?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
They drink only milk
Insects
Small animals
Regurgitated meat
Famous Wolves in Books
A werewolf is found in many folklore stories of European countries. Traditionally a werewolf would be a human that turns into a wolf. In the Harry Potter stories, there are two werewolf characters, with very different views on the role of werewolves.
 
Wachiwit/Shutterstock.com
Tania Volosianko/Shutterstock.com
This was one of Harry‚Äôs Defense Against the Dark Arts teachers.
Previous
Next
Which of these Harry potter characters have wolf connections?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
Draco Malfoy
Remus Lupin
Lord Woldemort
Professor Albus Dumbledore
Prehistoric Wolves
Pleistocene wolves were once found all over the northern hemisphere. They died out about 7,500 years ago. These wolves were quite similar to modern wolves but had a broader and shorter palate.
 
Aunt Spray/Shutterstock.com
Daniel Eskridge/Shutterstock.com
These wolves featured in Game Of Thrones.
Previous
Next
What prehistoric wolf lived in the Late Pleistocene epoch?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
Fenrir Wolves
Wexham Wolves
Custer Wolves
Dire Wolves
Symbiotic relationships
Very few mammals have symbiotic relationships with other animals. The wolf is an exception, where it tolerates another animal to get part of the kill. It is theorized that in some cases, the majority of the kill is harvested not by the wolf.
 
iStock.com/BlueBarronPhoto
Raven eating carrion/Shutterstock.com
These birds are sometimes called ‚Äúwolfbirds‚Äù.
Previous
Next
Which animal does the wolf have a symbiotic relationship with?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
Eagle
Raven
Bears
Common Vulture
Wolf Distribution
There are more than 30 subspecies of Canis lupus recognized, occurring throughout most of the world. Although wolves are considered the ancestors of domestic dogs, wolves and man does not have a good relationship in the wild.
 
davidhoffmann photography/Shutterstock.com
givaga/Shutterstock.com
The continent where camels and pyramids are found together.
Previous
Next
On which continent does wolves not appear naturally?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
Asia
Europe
North America
Africa
Wolves and People
Wolves have learned to fear people, as hunters will scare them off and even shoot them. Nevertheless, it is possible to come into close quarters with a wolf when hiking or mountain climbing. It is very important to follow the correct procedure, as a wolf can be very dangerous.
 
schaef71/Shutterstock.com
David Dirga/Shutterstock.com
If a predator has doubts, he will not attack a big animal.
Previous
Next
During an encounter with a wolf, what should you do?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
Run away as quick as you can
Stand still and make yourself look as tall as possible
Don‚Äôt look the wolf in the eye
Let your dogs loose so that they can attack
The Benefits Of Living In A Pack
A wolf pack can be considered to be a perfect team. They do everything together. They even care for each other and will nurture relationships within the pack.
 
Luke23/Shutterstock.com
Bildagentur Zoonar GmbH/Shutterstock.com
Although only one female will breed, everyone in the pack helps with the pups.
Previous
Next
Which of the following is not a benefit of living in a pack?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
They can hunt larger prey
Each wolf have a good change of breeding
Can compete against other packs for food
All the pups are raised by the whole pack
The Teeth of Wolves
Wolves have massive molars and very powerful jaws. They can easily bite through the femur of a moose, in six to eight bites! This is stronger than most breeds of dogs.
 
Dennis Jacobsen/Shutterstock.com
Daniel Korzeniewski/Shutterstock.com
A Wolf‚Äôs bite force is about the same as that of an Akita.
Previous
Next
What is the bite force of a wolf?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
150psi
400psi
1,000psi
750psi
Wolves Eating
A wolf‚Äôs favorite prey is large animals like deer, elk, and moose. They catch these animals as a pack and will feed together. If the animal is too large to eat at a single sitting, they will return again later to finish it off. Wolves can go for as long as two weeks between meals if the prey is scarce.
 
Geoffrey Kuchera/Shutterstock.com
AB Photographie/Shutterstock.com
Wolves can eat a little over 20lbs at one sitting.
Previous
Next
How much meat can a wolf eat at one meal?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
20-25lbs
30-32lbs
14-15lbs
9-10lbs
Wolf Life Expectancy
Wolf pups are born into the pack and are cared for by everyone. Wolves reach maturity at about 2 years when they are ready to mate. Because of their relatively dangerous lifestyle as hunters, some will die quite young, while others can live up to 14 years in the wild.
 
miroslav chytil/Shutterstock.com
Holly S Cannon/Shutterstock.com
The active wolf does not, on average, live 10 years or more.
Previous
Next
How old does a wolf get in the wild on average?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
9-10 years
4-5 years
12-14 years
6-8 years
The Composition of the Wolf Pack
Wolves live together in groups called packs. These packs work together to hunt and raise the pups. Wolves are extremely social animals and a strict hierarchy is followed in the pack.
 
AB Photographie/Shutterstock.com
Jim Cumming/Shutterstock.com
Wolves in a pack are usually all family.
Previous
Next
What does a wolf pack consist of?
Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer
Need Help? Clue is here
Need Help? Clue is here
A group of wolves who get on well together
Two leaders with wolves from other packs
A breeding pair and their offsping
Any group of wolves that cooperate
Big Wolves
Wolves are on average about 80 ‚Äì 100 pounds, which is bigger than the average dog. They are about 30 inches tall (measured at the shoulder). They are also longer than the average dog.
 
Volodymyr Burdiak/Shutterstock.com
Jim Cumming/Shutterstock.com
These wolves are native to Canada.
Previous
Next

Correct
Incorrect, CLICK TO REVEAL the correct answer

Arctic Wolf
Eurasian Wolf
Canadian Timber Wolf
Steppe Wolf
A Wolf‚Äôs Senses
A wolf, like other wild animals, relies heavily on its senses for survival. Their senses are all highly developed. They can hear and smell things that we humans can only see on electronic sensors.
 
Nature‚Äôs Charm/Shutterstock.com
FCG/Shutterstock.com
Wolves will make very good snifter dogs.
